author: Arundhati Nath
title: An insider's guide to Guwahati: more than just a gateway to India’s northeast | Cities
text:
In five words Beside Brahmaputra , surrounded by hills
Sound of the city “Adabari, adabari, jalukbari, jalukbari …” The shouts of the handymen working for the city buses in Guwahati can be heard throughout the day at the city bus stops. They call out the names of the few main destinations to which the bus is heading. After a while, it becomes a familiar, repeated chant.
Everyone’s tuning into … FM Radio stations. The popular channel is 92.7 Big FM . Some of the programs aired include Big Chah Gorom, Duporor Rodali, Yaadon ka Idiot Box and Full Volume. They telecast talk shows with entrepreneurs, celebrities, artists and local people and showcase local events like career or job fests, cultural or sports programs. These programs are interspersed with popular Assamese songs and old and new Bollywood hits.
Best venue? Srimanta Shankardev Kalakshetra is the favourite arts and culture centre. Named after the great Assamese reformer, saint and playwright, Srimanta Shankardev, this sprawling complex has hosted programmes such as World Music Day and Bishnu Rabha Divas recently. A magic show by the students of Jadu Samrat Vikram Talukdar was another popular evening.
Who’s top of the playlist? Angaraag Papon Mahanta is the current favourite among music buffs. His versatile singing is complemented by his creations – modern renditions of traditional Assamese folk music, like the Tokari, with modern electronic instruments. His performance in the popular series MTV Coke Studio has been widely applauded.
Best local artist Facebook Twitter Pinterest One of the many sculptures by Biren Singha that beautify the city. Photograph: Arundhati Nath
Born in 1951 in Chhaygaon, Assam, Biren Singha is one of the finest artists and sculptors that Assam has known. Growing up in abject poverty, this self taught artist initially designed signboards, hoardings, film posters and book covers before moving on to fine art and sculpture.
Today around 200 of his bronze and fibreglass sculptures beautify Guwahati city and several other parts of Assam. Biren Singha has spent nearly three decades studying Karbi life in the hills of Karbi Anglong, Assam. His first sculpture was of Rongpharpi Rongbe of Karbi Anglong at Diphu. He has also acted as art director on feature films such as Pani, Jirsong and The Untold Story of Blue Hills.
What’s the look on the street? Facebook Twitter Pinterest ‘Mixed and colourful’ … Guwahati street style. Photograph: Nikhi Gandha Gohain and Pubali Hazarika
The people of Guwahati are very stylish and love variety in their fashion. The look on the street is mixed and colourful. Many locals can be spotted in western wear. Women often wear kurtis (knee length upper garments), salwar kameezes (knee length blouses) and sarees (a nine-yard-long thin cloth elaborately draped around the body), or the traditional mekhela sador. Mekhela sador is an Assamese dress consisting of a cylindrical skirt worn with a blouse and a long piece of cloth draped around the body.
Everyone’s talking about … Everyone is discussing and debating the updating of the NRC or National Register of Citizens – a register containing details of all Indian citizens. Assam has been facing the problem of illegal migration from the neighboring country of Bangladesh and the government feels that updating the NRC will help solve this problem . People are hotly debating whether or not this exercise will help.
Best cultural Instagram Instagram isn’t very popular here yet, though there are some users. Streets of Assam is a cumulative photo journal by various photographers. Assam is rich in natural beauty and the pictures in this account reflect this very well. An elephant bathing in the river, a farmer going home or working in the paddy fields, scenes of the river Brahmaputra … these images make up daily life in Assam.
What Guwahati does better than anywhere else The people of Guwahati are known for their warmth and hospitality. Locals here live in harmony with several different ethnic groups from the north east and other states of the country. The kind of diversity seen in Guwahati is very rare to find.
Comedy gold Bhara Ghar, a comedy show aired on Rang Channel is the comedy hit of the moment. Bhara Ghar literally means rented house and the show portrays the hilarious happenings in Mr Kakoty’s family and the encounters with the different people living in his rented houses.
Moment from history In February 2007, the 33rd National Games were held in Guwahati amidst a huge cheering crowd of over 30,000 people. The mascot for the games was a torch-bearing baby rhino clad in the traditional dhoti (a piece of lower garment worn by males which is tied around the waist and extends to cover the legs) and gamocha (a hand woven traditional Assamese towel often gifted to loved ones). It was named Rongmon.
The 10 day event saw participation from more than 10,000 sportspersons. The closing ceremony was spectacularwith laser shows, live performances by well known singers Debojit Saha and Usha Uthup; Jhumur and Baghrumba dance and much more. This was the only time the National Games were hosted by Guwahati and it was a grand success.
Best street art Making an artistic stand … Yantr’s rhino. Photograph: Transhuman Collective A street artist from Guwahati who calls himself Yantr (a machine in English) has created an art piece depicting a bleeding rhino. Assam is world famous for one-horned rhinos and Yantr is protesting the rampant illegal poaching of this endangered animal through his art. The horn of the rhino sells for millions of dollars in the black market. This piece of art can be seen near the Assam State Zoo.
From me Born in 1989 in Guwahati, Arundhati Nath is a freelance writer who loves food, books, music, chocolates and travel.
